blocks.heading: Build customer trust even during downtime with Status Pages
blocks.description: We’ve built an easy and delightful way to communicate with customers during an incident with our public and private Status Pages.

cards.heading: Give users instant clarity and maximum transparency

blocks.heading: Effortless updates
blocks.description: Public, private and internal Status Pages are integrated with your incident response workflow, and have automatic and manual update capabilities. Have multiple Status Pages you need to update at once? Sub-pages allow you to do just that without any additional overhead.

blocks.heading: Publish faster
blocks.description: Automate your first update to let customers know you're on the case, create templates that pre-fill when you’re updating an incident, and then preview before you post for faster, more confident updates.

blocks.heading: Proactively communicate with subscribers
blocks.description: Customers can subscribe to receive updates their way: email, RSS, and even Slack allowing them to stay up to date on their terms.

accordionItems.label: What is an FAQ page?
accordionItems.content: An FAQ (Frequently Asked Questions) page is a key part of a knowledge base because it addresses the most common questions customers have and is useful to customers at all stages of the customer journey. FAQs start with a question and then answer it concisely. Within a [knowledge base template](https://www.zendesk.com/blog/knowledge-base-article-template/), FAQs can function as their own articles (e.g., "How do I set up a password?") or be incorporated into a longer series (e.g., "How to get started with your account"). Outside of the help center, a [chatbot](https://www.zendesk.com/service/messaging/chatbot/) can also provide support through FAQs.

accordionItems.label: How to create an FAQ page
accordionItems.content:
If you want to make an FAQ section that resonates with your customers, don’t just slap some ordinary questions and answers on a site page. Carefully think about what questions to include, consider who will answer (and how), and offer next-step solutions for when FAQs aren’t enough.

Tips for writing a good FAQ page

1. Use data to pick the right questions
2. Form clear criteria around responding
3. Offer multiple solutions
4. Track your progress
5. Make your FAQ page easy to find
